para.sentence: \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} – \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} possess hierarchies of rational solutions for special values of the parameters which are generated from “seed solutions” using the Bäcklundtransformations and often can be expressed in the form of determinants.
SeeAirault (1979).
Rational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize II}} exist for \alpha=n(\in\mathbb{Z}) and are generated using the seed solution w(z;0)=0 and the Bäcklund transformations (32.7.1) and (32.7.2).

More generally, w(z;n)=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\left(\ln\left(\frac{Q_{n-1}(z)}{Q_{n}(z) }\right)\right), where the Q_{n}(z) are monic polynomials (coefficient of highest power of z is 1 ) satisfying Q_{n+1}(z)Q_{n-1}(z)={zQ_{n}^{2}(z)+4\left(Q_{n}^{\prime}(z)\right)^{2}-4Q_{n} (z)Q_{n}^{\prime\prime}(z)}, with Q_{0}(z)=1 , Q_{1}(z)=z.
Next, let p_{m}(z) be the polynomials defined by p_{m}(z)=0 for m<0 , and \sum_{m=0}^{\infty}p_{m}(z)\lambda^{m}=\exp\left(z\lambda-\tfrac{4}{3}\lambda^ {3}\right).

Then for n\geq 2 w(z;n)=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}z}\left(\ln\left(\frac{\tau_{n-1}(z)}{\tau_ {n}(z)}\right)\right), where \tau_{n}(z) is the n\times n determinant \tau_{n}(z)=\begin{vmatrix}p_{1}(z)&p_{3}(z)&\cdots&p_{2n-1}(z)\\ p_{1}^{\prime}(z)&p_{3}^{\prime}(z)&\cdots&p_{2n-1}^{\prime}(z)\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ p_{1}^{(n-1)}(z)&p_{3}^{(n-1)}(z)&\cdots&p_{2n-1}^{(n-1)}(z)\end{vmatrix}.
For plots of the zeros of Q_{n}(z) see Clarkson and Mansfield (2003).

Special rational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} are w(z;\mu,-\mu\kappa^{2},\lambda,-\lambda\kappa^{4})=\kappa, w(z;0,-\mu,0,\mu\kappa)=\kappa z, w(z;2\kappa+3,-2\kappa+1,1,-1)=\dfrac{z+\kappa}{z+\kappa+1}, with \kappa , \lambda , and \mu arbitrary constants.
In the general case assume \gamma\delta\neq 0 , so that as in§32.2(ii)we may set \gamma=1 and \delta=-1.
Then \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} has rational solutions iff \alpha\pm\beta=4n, with n\in\mathbb{Z}.
These solutions have the form w(z)=\ifrac{P_{m}(z)}{Q_{m}(z)}, where P_{m}(z) and Q_{m}(z) are polynomials of degree m , with no common zeros.
For examples and plots see Milne et al. (1997); alsoClarkson (2003a).
For determinantal representations seeKajiwara and Masuda (1999).
Special rational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} are w_{1}(z;\pm 2,-2)=\pm\ifrac{1}{z}, , w_{2}(z;0,-2)=-2z, , w_{3}(z;0,-\tfrac{2}{9})=-\tfrac{2}{3}z.

There are also three families of solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} of the form w_{1}(z;\alpha_{1},\beta_{1})=\ifrac{P_{1,n-1}(z)}{Q_{1,n}(z)}, w_{2}(z;\alpha_{2},\beta_{2})=-2z+(\ifrac{P_{2,n-1}(z)}{Q_{2,n}(z)}), w_{3}(z;\alpha_{3},\beta_{3})=-\tfrac{2}{3}z+(\ifrac{P_{3,n-1}(z)}{Q_{3,n}(z)}), where P_{j,n-1}(z) and Q_{j,n}(z) are polynomials of degrees n-1 and n , respectively, with no common zeros.
In general, \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize IV}} has rational solutions iff either \alpha=m,\beta=-2(1+2n-m)^{2}, or \mspace{12.0mu }\alpha=m,\beta=-2(\tfrac{1}{3}+2n-m)^{2}, with m,n\in\mathbb{Z}.
The rational solutions when the parameters satisfy (32.8.22) are special cases of §32.10(iv).
For examples and plots see Bassom et al. (1995); alsoClarkson (2003b).
For determinantal representations seeKajiwara and Ohta (1998) and Noumi and Yamada (1999).

Special rational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} are w(z;\tfrac{1}{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\kappa(2-\mu),-\tfrac{1}{2}\kappa^{2})= \kappa z+\mu, w(z;\tfrac{1}{2},\kappa^{2}\mu,2\kappa\mu,\mu)=\kappa/(z+\kappa), w(z;\tfrac{1}{8},-\tfrac{1}{8},-\kappa\mu,\mu)=(\kappa+z)/(\kappa-z), with \kappa and \mu arbitrary constants.
In the general case assume \delta\neq 0 , so that as in §32.2(ii) we may set \delta=-\tfrac{1}{2}.

Then \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} has a rational solution iff one of the following holds with m,n\in\mathbb{Z} and \varepsilon=\pm 1 : \alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}(m+\varepsilon\gamma)^{2} and \beta=-\tfrac{1}{2}n^{2} , where n>0 , m+n is odd, and \alpha\neq 0 when |m|<n.
\alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}n^{2} and \beta=-\tfrac{1}{2}(m+\varepsilon\gamma)^{2} , where n>0 , m+n is odd, and \beta\neq 0 when |m|<n.
\alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}a^{2} , \beta=-\tfrac{1}{2}(a+n)^{2} , and \gamma=m , with m+n even.
\alpha=\tfrac{1}{2}(b+n)^{2} , \beta=-\tfrac{1}{2}b^{2} , and \gamma=m , with m+n even.
\alpha=\tfrac{1}{8}(2m+1)^{2} , \beta=-\tfrac{1}{8}(2n+1)^{2} , and \gamma\notin\mathbb{Z}.

These rational solutions have the form w(z)=\lambda z+\mu+(\ifrac{P_{n-1}(z)}{Q_{n}(z)}), where \lambda , \mu are constants, and P_{n-1}(z) , Q_{n}(z) are polynomials of degrees n-1 and n , respectively, with no common zeros.
Cases (a) and (b) are special cases of §32.10(v).
For examples and plots see Clarkson (2005).
For determinantal representations see Masuda et al. (2002).
For the case \delta=0 seeAirault (1979) and Lukaševič (1968).

Special rational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} are w(z;\mu,-\mu\kappa^{2},\tfrac{1}{2},\tfrac{1}{2}-\mu(\kappa-1)^{2})=\kappa z, w(z;0,0,2,0)=\kappa z^{2}, , w(z;0,0,\tfrac{1}{2},-\tfrac{3}{2})=\ifrac{\kappa}{z}, , w(z;0,0,2,-4)=\ifrac{\kappa}{z^{2}}, w(z;\tfrac{1}{2}(\kappa+\mu)^{2},-\tfrac{1}{2},\tfrac{1}{2}(\mu-1)^{2},\tfrac{ 1}{2}\kappa(2-\kappa))=\dfrac{z}{\kappa+\mu z}, with \kappa and \mu arbitrary constants.

In the general case, \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} has rational solutions if a+b+c+d=2n+1, where n\in\mathbb{Z} , a=\varepsilon_{1}\sqrt{2\alpha} , b=\varepsilon_{2}\sqrt{-2\beta} , c=\varepsilon_{3}\sqrt{2\gamma} , and d=\varepsilon_{4}\sqrt{1-2\delta} , with \varepsilon_{j}=\pm 1 , j=1,2,3,4 , independently, and at least one of a , b , c or d is an integer.
These are special cases of §32.10(vi).
